results.title: Dot in space
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross and Yoram Gross Films
results.brief_description: Dot’s new adventure takes her into outer space. She decides to resue Whyka, a Russian dog who is circling the Earth in a broken satellite. Once Dot saves Whyka, her troubles really begin. Her spacehip, Atlanta, crashes onto a planet called Pie-Arr-Squared. The inhabitants, called Roundies, imprison Dot and Whyka with the “Squaries”, unfortunate beings who are not considered round enough!

results.title: Doodlin': impressions of Len Lye
results.creator_credit: Keith Griffiths, Channel 4 and Koninek and Energy Source
results.brief_description: Directed by Keith Griffiths, famous for his art documentaries and his work with the Brothers Quay and Jan Svankmajer, “Doodlin’” explores the life and works of Len Lye. The importance of the landscape and his early years living in New Zealand, Australia and Samoa are explored as well as his introduction to the avant garde of London and Europe generally and later those of New York where he moved to in the 1940’s. Lively interviews with his close friends and collaborators include: film maker Stan Brakhage, wife Ann Lye, composer Jack Ellit, editor Paul Barnes, artist Ray Thorburn, biographer Roger Horrocks and John Matthews who worked with Lye on the engineering of his kinetic sculpture. Lye discusses the process of Doodlin’ as a means to unlock the subconscious and his work being ‘old brain stuff’. Great footage and examples of Lye making films using his pioneering ‘direct film’ technique in the making of “Free radicals” and “Particles in Space” (both 1979). Footage of sculptures include: ‘Universe’ (1976), ‘Blade’ (1976), and ‘Trilogy’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Griffiths, Channel 4 and Koninek and Energy Source

results.title: Dot and the Whale
results.brief_description: Our heroine Dot and her friend Neptune the dolphin find a whale stranded on an Australian beach and discover that to save her they must first find the old and wise ruler of the sea, Moby Dick. Using animation on beautifully filmed underwater live action scenes, this entertaining family film traces the exciting adventures of Dot and Neptune as they search for Moby Dick.

results.title: Doodle film
results.creator_credit: Donald Winkler, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The dossier of an inveterate doodler, a man whose compulsion to put scrawls and squiggles on everything at hand brings him to no good end, according to the narrator, at least. The commentary, delivered with the perspicacity of a coroner’s report, follows the development of the doodler’s mania from boyhood through adolescence to manhood, when it suddenly breaks all bounds. An amusing “case history” that some of us might identify with. Voice and narration provided by Maurice Podbrey. (Awards: Atlanta; Chicago)

results.title: Dot and the Smugglers
results.brief_description: A circus owner attempts to capture a mysterious Bunyip, but Dot and her bushland friends try to foil his plans. Dot soon discovers that the circus is merely a front for an international wildlife smuggling operation. Backed by her pals Burra the Kookaburra and two boxing Kangaroos, Dot goes on the warpath.

results.title: Donnie Darko [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Richard Kelly, Adam Fields, Nancy Juvonen, Sean McKittrick, Flower Films and Pandora Cinema
results.brief_description: The titular character of “Donnie Darko” is a troubled teenager who sleepwalks, suffers from apparant schizophrenia, struggles with his familial relations and is beset by visions of a six-foot demonic rabbit. The setting is 1988 and Donnie lives with his sympathetic parents and two sisters; a boy with friends, he is bullied by several school thugs and forms an attraction to a new girl in town, Gretchen. Donnie’s troubles multiply when the giant rabbit, named Frank, summons him from his bed one evening informing him that the world will end in approximately 28 days. Given that when he returns home his bedroom has been crushed by a falling aeroplane engine, Donnie suspects that Frank may be on to something. For the remainder of the film then, Donnie must try to make sense of this prophecy whilst fighting the sinister forces that compel him to commit acts of vandalism. Blending elements of the horror genre and the teenage coming-of-age flick, “Donnie Darko” also covers issues such as parenthood, sibling relationships, young love, time travel, destiny, student-teacher relations, paedophilia, conservatism in school curriculum, psychoanalysis, psychosis and imaginary friends. But “Donnie Darko” is more than just a clever pastiche of genre-awareness scenarios and a hip/clever postmodern appropriation of film-school inspirations; the film surpasses these limitations with a view that is creative, passionate, compelling and defiantly original.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Kelly, Adam Fields, Nancy Juvonen, Sean McKittrick, Flower Films and Pandora Cinema

results.title: Yves Saint Laurent: Valentino
results.creator_credit: Nicolas H Charney, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
Yves Saint Laurent: Follows the career of renowned French designer Yves Saint Laurent, heralding him as the master of modern couture. The course of fashion was set by Saint Laurent as he became one of the first designers to allow the streets to bear direct influence on his collections. Runway shows from throughout the designer’s career, from his heading of Dior at the age of just 22, to the late ‘90’s, illustrate the longevity of his signature pieces, such as the controversial see-through blouse. Saint Laurent’s long association with French actress Catherine Deneuve is highlighted in interviews and photography. Other interviews include those with the designer himself, and with Jean Loup Sieff and Phillip Miller. “Valentino”: Extensive interviews with the Italian designer Valentino reveal his design philosophy and his beginnings at the age of seventeen. Working for Jean Desse and then Guy Laroche, Valentino quickly established a reputation for himself as a talented designer of women’s fashion. At the time of production the designer’s business was generating $600 million a year in couture and associated lines such as fragrances and accessories. The signatures of the Valentino design are explored, including his all white collections, his prominent use of black and white and the bow. Interviews with a plethora of celebrities including Christy Turlington, Sophia Loren, Sylvester Stallone, Bette Midler and Brooke Shields culminate in a review of the 1991 Park Avenue Armory Valentino exhibition. Valentino is portrayed as a ‘slave to perfection’, and the unchallenged leader of Italian fashion.

results.title: Giorgio Armani: Calvin Klein
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
A fascinating documentary focusing on two of fashions most sought-after designers. Giorgio Armani is regarded as one of fashion’s master tailors, and was also one of the first designers to actively seek patronage from Hollywood, coming to prominence after Richard Gere wore an Armani blazer in the film American Gigolo. As a result, the name Armani is synonymous with wealth, elegance and prestige. Calvin Klein, on the other hand, is more famous as a brand name and an image. Klein became a household name after launching a brand of designer jeans, with a controversial advertising campaign featuring a young Brooke Shields. His simple yet appealing designs and lack of interest in adopting seasonal trends have helped him to build a successful billion dollar business.

results.title: Donald Brittain: filmmaker
results.creator_credit: Kent Martin, Adam Symansky and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Donald Brittain was one of the most respected documentary filmmakers of his time and his work with the National Film Board of Canada earned him accolades from his peers and cemented his place in cinema history. This documentary examines the man behind the work and the work itself. He created films about heroes, “exposed villians” and offered filmgoers a “warts and all” expose of his subject and themes. This excellent documentary presents a frank and honest account of Brittain whose gift is described as being able to make the great man common and the common man great.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kent Martin, Adam Symansky and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Greatest designers: Paris: Karl Lagerfeld
results.creator_credit: Rebecca Reeder, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Designers”.
The Greatest Designers: Paris focusses on the work and influence of a selection of French fashion designers, including Chanel, Paul Poiret, Jacques Firth, Elsa Schiaparelli, Cristobal Balenciaga, Hubert de Givenchy, Emanuel Ungaro, Andre Courreges, Pierre Cardin, and Thierry Mugler. Karl Lagerfeld, considered one of the most prolific designers of the twentieth century, is renouned for both his highly-priced ready-to-wear fashion and his philosophical quotes on the business of fashion designing. His designs, capable of turning any woman into a star, are mostly light and fluid in their construction. He worked in couture as an assistant for several years before becoming a freelance designer, which ultimately led him to developing his own signature line, as well as designing for Fendi, Chloe, and Chanel. In the 1980’s, Lagerfeld was responsible for rejuvenating the Chanel label by adapting the Chanel suit and re-working it in weird and wonderful ways.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rebecca Reeder, Marlene McGinnis Cardin and Videofashion
